review.title: Probabilistic Description Logics
review.abstract: On the one hand, classical terminological knowledge representation excludes the possibility of handling uncertain concept descriptions involving, e.g., "usually true" concept properties, generalized quantifiers, or exceptions. On the other hand, purely numerical approaches for handling uncertainty in general are unable to consider terminological knowledge. This paper presents the language ACP which is a probabilistic extension of terminological logics and aims at closing the gap between the two areas of research. We present the formal semantics underlying the language ALUP and introduce the probabilistic formalism that is based on classes of probabilities and is realized by means of probabilistic constraints. Besides inferring implicitly existent probabilistic relationships, the constraints guarantee terminological and probabilistic consistency. Altogether, the new language ALUP applies to domains where both term descriptions and uncertainty have to be handled.
histories: Appears in Proceedings of the Tenth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI1994)

referenceMentions.context: Research in knowledge representation led to the de­ velopment of terminological logics [Nebel, 1990] which originated mainly in Brachman's KL-ONE [Brachman and Schmolze, 1985] and are called description log­ ics [Patil et al.

Research in knowledge representation led to the de­ velopment of terminological logics [Nebel, 1990] which originated mainly in Brachman's KL-ONE [Brachman and Schmolze, 1985] and are called description log­ ics [Patil et al.

Systems like BACK, CLASSIC, LOOM, KANDOR, KL-TWO, KRIS, KRYPTON, MESON, SB-ONE, and YAK (for overview and analyses see [Sigart Bulletin, 1991; Heinsohn et al., 1994]) make use of a separation of terminological and assertional knowledge.
, [Kruse et al., 1991]) in general are unable to consider termino­ logical knowledge.
From the viewpoint of interval-valued probabilistic constraints, our work has been influenced by the early paper [Dubois and Prade, 1988], where first probabilis­ tic constraints were presented.
In this framework the system INFERNO [Quinlan, 1983] also has to be men­ tioned since it is based on the intuition of comput­ ing "maximally consistent ranges" underlying the lan­ guage .
One consequence is that the integrated ter­ minological and probabilistic formalism is able to ap­ ply refined constraints if necessary [Heinsohn, 1991; Heinsohn, 1992].
AfJ::P, the formal framework, the associated interval-valued constraints, proofs, and other related work can be found in [Heinsohn, 1993].

metadata.abstractText: On the one hand, class ical terminological knowledge representation excludes the possi­ bility of handling uncertain concept descrip­ tions involving, e.g., "usually true" concept properties, generalized quantifiers, or excep­ tions. On the other hand, purely numer­ ical approaches for handling uncertainty in general are unable to consider terminologi­ cal knowledge. This paper presents the lan­ guage At:CP which is a probabilistic extension of terminological logics and aims at closing the gap between the two areas of research. We present the formal semantics underlying the language At:CP and introduce the prob­ abilistic formalism that is based on class­ es of probabilities and is realized by means of probabilistic constraints. Besides infer­ ing implicitly existent probabilistic relation­ ships, the constraints guarantee terminologi­ cal and probabilistic consistency. Altogether, the new language .AirP applies to domains where both term descriptions and uncertain­ ty have to be handled.
